data.text: you soak it in the crock pot and it gets inside the pins and rollers where it lubricates where the friction is. Most of the outside drips off and is gone (the stuff in the outside) the first time you wash the bike. H pits a bit of a process cleaning and lubing, but I do batches of 6 at a time so I‚Äôm usually set for 4-6 months. It‚Äôs certainly not for everyone, but it‚Äôs the cleanest most buttery chain imaginable.

data.text: I see. I think people use way too much lube to begin with but I've always used TriFlow and never have a dirty drivetrain. From my experiences with wax lubes it clumps up with all the dirt and harder to clean.
data.author: Sean Gates

data.text: I used liquid wax for quite some time.. Squirt and Silca with great results although I did have to put it on after every ride. Up in Tahoe when the dirt gets dry we have ‚Äúmoon dust‚Äù and around the 50km mark chains start to make noise with the dust collecting on the chain so I carry a little 10ml bottle of lube to reapply mid ride when necessary. With the hot melt wax I can typically go twice the distance without and noise. When I wash the bike I use a scrub brush and soapy water and it cleans the dust off and it‚Äôs good to go again. In summer I get 200 to 500km out of a hot wax. Last winter I rode my fat bike all season on the same hot wax chain. There is zero dust on snow and my bikes sty clean until spring when I start getting into some mud
